Review title: I think they spent all the budget on Bruce Willis and had nothing left for writing, props, actors and more.
Review_body: I noticed that "Cosmic Sin" recently made it to IMDB's infamous Bottom 100 list and has a pitiful score of only 2.5! So, not only is it on the list...but it is way up the list at #39!When I first started watching this sci-fi film, I could IMMEDIATELY see why the film is so hated. It's a film set in the 26th century and at this time, there is space travel and life on many planets and moons. So, why do you see folks driving pickup trucks that look like they are from 2021? Why are the clothes pretty much what you'd see today and why are most of the weapons not much more effective or different than today's?! It honestly looks like they must have spend all their budget on securing Bruce Willis' talents and had nothing left to make it look like a futuristic story. Now I don't think you need expensive props to make a good film...but this is ridiculous and really takes you out of the story.The story begins with some form of life being discovered on some new planet. It seems that up until this time, humans have never made first contact with any intelligent species...even with humans inhabiting many new worlds. As you'd expect, this new form of sentient life is not sweet and friendly....as who would want to see a film like that?! And, it turns out that it is so deadly that in the entire galaxy (numbering many, many, many billions) the only guy that can stop the creatures is a war criminal, James Ford (Willis)!I have seen much worse films that never made it to the IMDB list...mostly because they are older, cheaper and more obscure. In other words, the Bottom 100 is very heavily skewed to new films...so although the film is bad, it's not the 39th worst film ever made! I think it's just that a lot of folks get Netflix and had a chance to see it...whereas far less folks have seen the films of Ed Wood, Al Adamson, Ray Dennis Steckler and William Grefe...all filmmakers who REALLY knew how to make terrible films...REALLY terrible films!So is there anything good about this movie? Some of the CGI space scenes are very nice and would probably look great on the big screen (though I assume this film, when it came out, only went straight to Netflix and Amazon Prime). Otherwise, the story is not especially interesting, the dialog often pretty bad and the acting not especially good. It is not completely awful...just mostly awful. And, unfortunately not so bad that it's fun to watch in order to make fun of the film.By the way, nearly all the reviews for this are extremely negative. With this and a score of 2.5, I am amazed to find some folks giving it 10s! A few admit that it's bad but are just trolling or love it because it's so bad. A few, however, are VERY short reviews that talk about how brilliant it is...a sure sign normally of fake reviews done by folks connected with the film...which is pretty shameful.

Some 500 years in the future, mankind has spread into the cosmos. On a faraway planet, humans have encountered First Contact. An alien presence infects people and turns them into marauding zombies. James Ford (Bruce Willis) is a disgraced military leader arguing for the doomsday Q-bomb. Engineer Fiona Ardene (Adelaide Kane) is called in to prep the device. General Ryle (Frank Grillo) leads the soldiers while Dr. Lea Goss (Perrey Reeves) is awed by the aliens.First thing first, this movie opens with an info-dump in text form. It's a lot of gobbledygook. Someone should try to read it again. Then there is the awkward mix of present-day technology with the future tech. There is no logical reason for it. It's an obviously sign of bad budgeting and unimaginative set design. When that happens, they are better off putting the movie in a smaller space and as much future tech onto the screen. At least, put some effort in giving the characters some future-cars. Its greater sin is that it's boring. I think I must have spaced out. One moment, they're fighting zombies in the warehouse and the next, they're space-diving to another planet. It's a forgettable muddle.

The Earth looks very much like it does today minus the robot bar tender. Slang terms like "Secret Squirrel" is still being used. The character development was light and I had flashbacks to Willis blowing up an asteroid. I understand the lack of love. It is an action film with lots of gun fighting and C.J. Perry. Not the best, but strangely I enjoyed it a bit.Guide: F-word. No sex or nudity.

Review title: "Either way this works out, it's gonna be on the wrong side of history."
Review_body: Ah yes, a movie that's finally described by it's own title. This film doesn't require a long review because it's just too disjointed for a coherent story line, what with all those scenes that look like they might be dream sequences or flashbacks to another time and place. They just don't seem to connect to what's going on in the main picture. Sad to say, I was looking for Bruce Willis to break out of his recent string of dismal flicks to really make an impact in this one, but he just looked way tired of the whole thing as Blood General James Ford, the banished soldier who dropped a Q-bomb on planet Zafdie to wipe out seventy million people. All for a good cause of course, because they were on the way to secede from the Alliance with Earth and Ellora. Ford has the film's most prescient bit of dialog, which I've put in my summary line for you. Along with the title, it pretty much says everything you need to know about this sci-fi travesty.

Granted, I have to admit that I was lured in to watching the 2021 movie "Cosmic Sin" given the movie's cover/poster and the fact that the movie was starring Bruce Willis, Frank Grillo and Costas Mandylor.And let me just come right out and say that writers Edward Drake and Corey Large failed to deliver a wholesome movie here with "Cosmic Sin". While I managed to sit through the entire ordeal, then I must say that all throughout the course of the entire movie I was sitting with an overwhelming sense of pointlessness. I just couldn't find anything worthwhile in the storyline, and everything seemed just bland and without a cause.It was so difficult to indulge myself into the storyline because it was so linear and anything but interesting and exciting. So the end result that is "Cosmic Sin" from director Edward Drake was just a very forgettable and rather mundane movie. The storyline was just so amazingly generic and linear that you could have left the movie for a longer period of time, and returned only to be right up to speed with the storyline.Now, I am sure that die-hard fans - pardon the pun - of Bruce Willis or Frank Grillo might actually find some kind of odd enjoyment here in the movie. I, however, didn't. So this movie was a swing and a miss.I must admit that it felt that Bruce Willis wasn't really committed to this movie project, and his performance felt half-hearted, as if he was running on auto-pilot. And Frank Grillo just wasn't given enough on-screen time to manage to do much of anything to salvage the movie.The characters in the movie were every bit as bland and pointless as the storyline. So you don't really connect with any of them, nor do you form any kind of attachments to any of them. So whether they live or die, it hardly matters.Now, what did work for "Cosmic Sin" was the visuals. They had some nice enough suits for the soldiers of the Alliance. And the weapon effects were quite good. The aliens, however, they just felt like something out of a B movie. So that was disappointing to say the least.All in all, "Cosmic Sin" was exactly what the movie title says; a cosmic sin. This movie came and went without leaving much of any blast mark or memorable impression. My rating of "Cosmic Sin" lands on a mere three out of ten stars.

A terribly written trash heap that made no sense, the storyline was disjointed to say the least. The effects were okay. But what good there was is overshadowed by poor acting and bad dialogue. Almost laughably bad.
Cosmic Sin is goofy, with thriller dance, tower defense, nonsense. Bad characters, intangible silly plot, yawn end please.

Note that he is billed first, above Willis, and his role is at most 15 minutes from the film anyway.But what makes this film shine like a black hole is the story. It felt more than devoid of passion, like a spreadsheet that sucks one's soul away in the accounting department on a hot day after the air conditioning died. I mean, if a kid would have written it, it at least would have been fun. If someone was incompetent it would have felt like trying to send some kind of message, however badly. But no, it ... just made no sense, like someone hated writing for this film.Bottom line: it is so bad you can't even enjoy it wasted. It's a non-movie. It's like what's on the other side of the event horizon of TV static.

Review title: A Faint Potential For A Engaging Sci Fi Movie Falls To Poor Writing and Execution
Review_body: In Cosmic Sin the 26th Century still using way outdated hand weapons (eventually even a grenade) and pick-up trucks and honking vehicles on a street and parked motorcycles and even cigarettes indistinguishable from the 1960s. The Nostromo from the Alien (1979) had a way much better med unit. Early scenes after the good and bad introductory mystery have of course the requisite robotic servers and hologram (country?) singers and a barfight with a slight difference with again the old-fashioned side arms and the Calvary with an attempt at twinge of an alternative outcome that really is not.There are major storyline problems with the quarantine procedures even simple glass windows and even a typical "gun" fight, yet there was an initial attempt at fascinating underlying dynamic taking place however with the first contact encounter scenes and subsequent reflective commentary. Then somehow a brief firefight does not flow well, problems with editing arise, a scene very underdeveloped, and supposedly a well-manned defensive team becomes at risk of being actually overrun. Instead of a quickening climatic pace, the energy seems to dissipate and slow down along with almost no high-tech, futuristic surveillance networks to warn of impending attacks becomes more combat scenes from a mediocre World War II movie with elements from Stargate (1994) and worse yet the climatic battle is something that would be more like out of a World War I engagement and lame hand to hand sequences and a limp effort a riveting emotional end. The screenwriters were definitely not up the job and no actor could improve on a thin script that had the promise but not the actual substance to translate into a credible movie. This movie even reverted to absolutely unnecessary cowboy, western era musical harmonics while Bruce Willis strangely just seems to fade almost completely away by the end of the movie.The major problem with Cosmic Sin lies with the screenwriters trying too hard to be cute and offer up something substance, different, and try to incorporate too many fancy relational and philosophical ideas. They failed in their execution and omitted too many important backstories to offer audiences a sense of plot flow. Instead the audience is sort of just dropped into this movie without the understanding of what the real motives of what is going on. The audience is forced to play catch up. The writers fall into their own traps with the only way out of empty ideas is to create overly convenient ways to extricate themselves out of various corners (i.e., where a general loses face for backing down on his own orders, the awkward political dynamics of the military decisions being made, past undisclosed relationships).Maybe the only nice surprise of this movie is the character and what some people might call a cameo performance of Lochlyn Munro. He appears to have finally broken out of his typecast of either simple bad guy or side character in a slew of romantic comedies. Munro had a decent performance here.

I sort of wonder whether there is a minimum word count for IMDB reviews, but then again I suspect there isn't if the number of reviews that appear that simply say 'I created an account to give this movie one star' is anything to go by. Mind you, those reviews generally don't tell me all that much, though the star rating generally does go to help the final score, not that this tells me anything these days with the number of single review accounts that seem to appear with all of the movies these days.However, this movie definitely deserves one star - it is bad - really, really bad. Okay, I was pretty tired when I watched this film, and found it rather difficult to follow, and normally that would suggest that maybe I should watch this film again. However, this film literally have the lowest rating that I have seen of any film on IMDB - and that is definitely saying something. It sounds as if nobody who watched the film enjoyed it. In fact, nobody has even bothered to write a synopsis on Wikipedia.What is it about? Honestly, I'm not all that sure. Is it an alien invasion that the people of Earth have to stop, or are they zombies trying to take over the Earth, and the people of Earth have to stop them. Yeah, it is pretty confusing, and doesn't seem to really have a coherent plot. Also, what is this thing about going out and destroying the aliens before they can, well, take over the Earth? That doesn't seem to be the type of thing that we should be advocating.Yeah, this film was incredibly painful to watch, and I really couldn't wait for it to be over. Sure, I could have simply walked out of the cinema, but I really don't like doing that - at all. I pretty much like to hang around until the end. Sure, I might watch it again if it appears on Netflix, but then again with all of the other films out there that I could be wasting my time watching, this one isn't going to be high on my list.

I saw "Cosmic Sin", starring Frank Grillo-the Purge movies, Captain America:The Winter Soldier; Bruce Willis-Breach, Glass; Costas Mandylor-Born Champion, the Saw movies and Perrey Reeves-Old School, Child's Play 3.
This is a bad 'B' sci_fi movie with Bruce Willis getting second billing-you know there is something wrong there. He just recently made another cheap sci_fi movie, Breach, so I guess he must like them-either that or maybe he owes somebody money or a favor. Anyway, this one takes place in 2524, when the earth has colonized some other planets, some of which were inhabited. Bruce was a war hero-he killed a bunch of aliens-but some people didn't like the way he did it, so he was discharged unceremoniously. Some aliens attack a group of earth people on a remote survey planet and Frank-a general-calls in Bruce to do what Bruce likes doing; putting the aliens in their place. Costas is a Sargent in the squad that is assembled and Perrey is a doctor/former love interest to Bruce. Some of the story is a little jumbled and hard to make sense of at times-the aliens are wearing long blazers with hoodies to probably hide the low budget. There are even times when it's hard to tell exactly who the good guys are-the humans or the aliens. Of course, that might have been the producers objective in the first place; to have a debate on war.
It's rated "R" for violence and language and has a running time of 1 hour & 28 minutes.
I like bad movies-at times-but they do need a coherent storyline, at least. I wouldn't buy this on DVD. I wouldn't rent it either. If you really want to see it, I would wait until it shows up on cable.

Review title: Far from cosmic; the true sin has been committed by those that produced and worst still green lit this film!!
Review_body: When a small group of soliders on a remote planet are attacked by a mysterious alien civilisation another team of soliders headed up by disgraced retired General James Ford must work together and bring the fight to the aliens before they destroy Earth and the various other civilisations...I'm really starting to get sick of Sky Movies and their misleading ratings for films; 4 stars out of 5 this rubbish got from them (so 8 out of 10 on the IMDB scale). After I watched the film I decided to look at its IMDB rating to see what others thought of the film and was relieved to see that I wasn't alone in thinking this was a stinker (it's current rating of 2.5 out of 10 speaks for itself).Although many other people will have doubtlessly explained the many flaws with this film I may as well throw my hat in the ring and give my two penneth...For a start, despite the film only running for around 85-90 minutes it is excruciatingly slow with a practically non-existent storyline; I mean there's no real definitive explanation for what the aliens wanted and why they were attacking these civilisations in the first place? At one point it's mentioned that the aliens don't believe that they can co-exist with other civilisations and therefore effectively rather than destroy the people within the civilisations. They embody the people and use them as hosts to continue their destruction (effectively creating an army). This is summed up in about 30 seconds of dialogue and isn't eluded to again. To say this film lacks depth would be an understatement!!!Still shallow sci-fi isn't always bad, but if you're not going to give your audience a deep and involving story then it's usually a good idea to provide a shedload of action, sharp dialogue, interesting characters and a sense of fun. OK it's asking a lot to see all 4 elements, but even 1 or 2 of these things may have made the film just about bearable, but honestly the film is so colourless and so devoid of personality that it becomes a challenge just to sit through it.The acting is pretty poor as well; Bruce Willis isn't the best actor in the world, but he has appeared in a lot of good films meaning that if he is working with the right director and screenwriter they know this and will play to his strengths. To be honest though, given how bad this film was I think Bruce knew he was starring in a turkey and simply didn't care and therefore put no effort in at all. Everyone else is no better with many of the cast reciting their dialogue in an emotionless manner as though they were reading from an autocue. Oh and by the way guys you're meant to be soldiers so something in the way of camaraderie wouldn't have gone a miss.Believe its abysmal IMDB rating and the 1 or 2 star reviews, save 90 minutes of your life and just skip this rubbish.

Review title: ANOTHER CHEAP 'N' CHEESY SCI-FI B-MOVIE WITH WILLIS!!!
Review_body:
EDWARD DRAKE who directed this very low-budget t.v series like Sci-fi Thriller also had written it & also had written the other Bruce Willis Sci-fi Cheapy ANTI-LIFE (2021) also & that explains why both films are so similar & i thought that as I watching it, i actually said to my wife that Willis must've gotten Deya Vu making this!!!
I actually liked ANTI-LIFE better of the two but to be honest they do make a chilled evening of a Double Bill of Willis Sci-fi Thriller's.
Now COSMIC SIN is set like it's other half of the Double bill, in the future but this time the world isn't destroyed but just very futuristic (with what the small budget could do) with flying cars/vehicles as well as normal cars too still & robots for a barman in the bars (Similar to Will Smith's i,Robot 2004) & lots of glowing Neon lights & things & for the most part it looks good!!! Yes it's very low-budget but i gotta admit i was impressed with alot of the look & technology they pulled off with cheap c.g.i & practical effects & the basic story is our planet has finally made contact with Alien creatures but they're hostile & when a team return from another planet that they've been stationed on, they come back possessed just like in it's close brother ANTI-LIFE & start killing everyone in the station base & here we get our team of soon-to-be heroes with the rugged old infamous ex-Commander Bruce Willis known as a warmonger due to his brutal past & it's just nice having the old skool Action legend here in such a low-budget production, even if he's only here for the paycheck!!! Willis plays his part like most these days with a calmness & a Coolness & a bad attitude just like he did in Anti-life & many other of his DTV films but i like him here & just by having him lifts its quality.
We also get the great B-movie legend FRANK GRILLO who i have loved since THE PURGE: ANARCHY & his Cool, rugged & no-nonsense toughness is on display again in a leader role but to be honest he doesn't get to do the action i expected & wanted but again it's great to have the veteran side by side with Willis.
There's a few other familiar faces but it's these two stars is why i wanted to even watch this.I will say this though that i would rather watch this flick or Anti-life over any of the ridiculously mega budget TRANSFORMERS films & more so than many of the over-blown budget trash that is put on the Cinema, Cosmic Sin is small scale but crams in a fun little Sci-fi action story with a Cool Willis leading it all even if he's not exactly giving it his all, still miles better than the usual Steven Seagal DTV flick.
Small minimalist budget yes but i see alot of creativity went into creating the look & it's futuristic technology & it does look Good for it's budget!!!
At times i got the feel & vibe of a POWER RANGERS episode or movie, especially when they gear up with body armour suits & when they fight the Alien beings (that seem like possessed humans as you Don't ever see their faces or what they really are) the villains come accross as the type that the Power Rangers would battle but hey it's a Low-budget slice of Sci-fi Thriller cheese so i just took it for that.
Our team are power boosted through space & land on another planet that is fine for Humans & the rest of the Cheese fest plays on the forest planet with rebels (like STAR WARS) & the action is fine for a cheap flick with laser guns & possessed warriors that also reminded of John Carpenter's Ghost's of Mars just like ANTI-LIFE did too!!!! Many Sci-fi flicks enfluenced this as did ANTI-LIFE & like i said both written by Edward Drake but only this one was directed by him.Cosmic Sin just like Anti-life is a cheap, trashy & cheesy but fun B-movie that's nothing special or great but an easy watch & does make a nice Double bill with ANTI-LIFE. Entertaining & fun.

Review title: VIEWS ON FILM review of Cosmic Sin
Review_body: "It takes a monster to kill a monster". Guess what. It takes a miracle to believe that 2021's Cosmic Sin would be viable, sci-fi fare. By the way, Neil Blomkamp called and says he wants his lauded integrity back.So yeah, "Sin" was released in March of this year (its title in India is actually Worthless Rip-Off). It's a direct-to-video flick that also poses as something you'd see on well, the Syfy channel. Cosmic Sin tries to be part Blade Runner, part Ghosts of Mars, part Elysium, and part Aliens. Sadly with its characters bickering back and forth like the Bickersons, "Sin" feels more like 2000's veritable bomb, Supernova.Cosmic Sin is poorly lit in a soft bulb sort of way. It also has action scenes that are choppily edited, actresses you feel sorry for (I'm talking about you Perrey Reeves), and a script that contains enough sci-fi mumbo jumbo to denounce any normal ritual. Bruce Willis stars in "Sin" and you know what that means. Aside from unloading a rifle, projecting his last shred of screen presence, and looking like Iron Man without full headgear, Brucie appears like he's in a coma with no chance of reverse stupor.Taking place in the year 2524 (that's random) and directed by Australian Edward Drake, Cosmic Sin is basically about Gen. James Ford (Bruce Willis) trying to stop a fleet of aliens that I guess look like humans. Willis doesn't do or say much but hey, he's Bruce "I used to be a beast" Willis. He probably got paid by the line (or any catatonic facial expression).Bottom line: Any way you cut it, I probably should've avoided watching Cosmic Sin. Its intentions are good considering but come on, it's more like "cosmic" debris (no pun intended for the late Frank Zappa). Forgive me for I have "sinned".

It's a low budget sci-fi film but it has an excellent cast and I liked some of the scenes, I think they did well with the low budget and it was a lot better than the other Bruce Willis sci-fi anti-life.

Review title: Were this a no budget film released on YouTube by some students for free I'd recommend it, but as a product by a professional studio with Bruce Willis in the lead it's trash.
Review_body: In the year 2524 an Earth colony has first contact with a hostile alien race. General Ryle (Frank Grillo) enlists disgraced "Blood General" James Ford (Bruce Willis) who was infamous for his use of a Q-Bomb that killed 70 Million people. Ryle enlists Ford to lead an off the books team to eliminate the alien threat before they're aloud to spread through the galaxy.Reteaming with Edward Drake and Corey Large of fellow DtV Willis sci-fi film Breach, Cosmic Sin looks and feels like it's from the same filmmakers to the point they almost feel like entries in their own "universe". Instead of aping Alien or The Thing like Breach, Cosmic Sin is more in line with sci-fi action like Aliens or Edge of Tomorrow. In a way I suppose Cosmic Sin is a marginal improvement on Breach, but in other ways with a larger scale story and a similar production budget, it feels noticeably cheaper than Breach as well.Much like Breach the movie doesn't feel like it takes place in the future. At least with Breach once they were on the ship they at least had proper uniforms that fit with the situation, but in Cosmic Sin everything feels like it's straight from today save for some CGI establishing shots of spaceships and some "armor"(we'll get to that). It's clear the movie's reach far exceeds it's grasp with the "high tech military facility" using the same tricks as breach to make it look futuristic with harsh multicolored lighting and poorly integrated hologram effects. But the filmmakers luckily decided to give us some locational variety with their shoot....the woods! All of the colony scenes (save for one scene with a tent) take place in the woods and have the same feeling of rushed and economic one would expect to see in a LARP straight out of Role Models. The armor the characters wear in the second half of the movie makes no sense as the script says it's approved for "quantum combat"(whatever that's supposed to be) and with open faced helmets and massive bare patches there's no thought or care as to how these cheap bulky monstrosities function in combat or space.Outside of the bare bones production values, the movie's script is a hodgepodge of pretty much every other sci-fi film/video game you've seen(and a few you haven't) with the likes of the 2009 Star Trek, Stargate, Edge of Tomorrow, Screamers, Gears of War, Aliens, and even Ghosts of Mars. The movie's script also tries to address "ethical issues" in quite possibly the most ill fitting approach since 2005's Stealth tried to analyze the moral issues of unmanned drone warfare. Willis' "Blood General" James Ford is so named because he quelled an separatist rebellion by dropping a Q-bomb killing 70 million people. The movie is strangely uncritical about this character with many of the supporting cast spouting things about how Ford got a "Raw Deal", "It's harder to give orders than follow them", "you need monsters to beat monsters", and it's the kind of mindset that many villains use for justification in many films of this ilk that makes the film feel fundamentally confused. Not that the story will draw most people in as it's poorly delivered with bad camera work, poorly staged sequences, and sleepy performances from uninterested actors with Bruce Willis' voice never even breaking an octave.Cosmic Sin continues Bruce Willis' disappointing DtV streak with an embarrassing cheap sci-fi rehash that is put to shame by amateurly made fan productions. With a sloppy production, cut and paste script, and uninterested performances that leave the movie inert and dull the movie will give you the odd laugh or smirk from point out its stolen ideas and concepts, but aside from that it's yet another cheap dud from a once respectable actor.

This film is just a mess. I hope that the intention behind this was to make some easy cash.
Otherwise, I just can't explain why would anyone get involved in this.There are outlines of a story, but not like an actual screenplay. Review title: A terrible movie... Bruce should fire his agent
Review_body: From the first 30seconds of the movie, I already knew this movie was going to be trash, but I didn't realize just HOW trash it was going to be. This is a 3rd-rate movie that hitched their ENTIRE wagon onto Bruce Willis' name... without him nobody would even have bothered streaming this movie, nevermind watching it at the theatres.This movie HAS TO have had a budget below $15mil..... it would be an absolute travesty if they spent anything more than that on this terrible movie. And I'm sorry but if you're going to attempt to make a 'sci-fi space epic adventure film' on a budget of $15mil or less then you're just insane. 1 or 2mil probably went to Bruce and that left the rest of the movie with an already shoe-string budget. The CGI is bad. The editing is bad. The majority of the movie takes place in darkness, so they didn't have to spend money on set-pieces. There's an INSANE amount of vignetting, lens flare and vaseline-lens going on as well, which is a huge indicator of a terrible production. Easily 30% of the movie is show with vaseline on the lens, I'm certain of it.There's SO MANY things that this movie COULD have done differently to make it seem like it had a bigger budget. Upgrade (2018) is a FANTASTIC example of how to make a sci-fi film with NO budget. I mean Upgrade (2018) had a $3mil budget which is absolutely insane, and if you watched that movie then you'd know that it certainly didn't seem like a shoe-string budgeted movie. Really the fault comes down on the bad director of this movie and just the whole production team as well (since the editing and framing of this movie is terrible too).This movie has no real redeemable qualities and I'd HIGHLY recommend that you watch something else instead. This movie is literally a waste of time and the only one who probably benefitted from this experience is Bruce Willis since he can walk away with a cool couple million (although I respect him less as an actor because of this movie now).

Whilst Bruce's career is like a damaged satellite out in space, there may be moments of sparks but more often it is on a downward trajectory heading to crash land into the dark abyss.This is not the worst entry to date but it is sad to watch a once Hollywood A Lister descends into less than B Movie star.Anyway this Martian film has a basic storyline that is very predictable. It delivers what it set out to do. It reminds me of Armageddon (when Bruce Willis was at his peak of Hollywood stardom) & Mission to Mars. This is a personification of a Alzheimer's disease in film form in that is tragic & it will soon be forgotten but for the right reasons: it adds nothing to this genre of films & the idea that aliens are all evil is so generic. The scenes in which Bruce Willis sits at the bar hits hard as it juxtaposed the idea of character procastinating their time on drinks & how Bruce is now wasting our time on things he must signed in on for the paychecks!

Review title: It was a Cosmic Sin" green lighting this movie!
Review_body:
"Cosmic Sin" is not the Original Sin, but green lighting this movie was.
Here's what the makers of this movie would like to tell you:
Bruce Willis and Frank Grillo star in the new epic sci-fi adventure set in the year 2524, four hundred years after humans started colonising the outer planets.
Retired Military General James Ford (Willis) is called back into service after soldiers on a remote planet are attacked by a hostile alien fleet.
The threat against the human race escalates into an inevitable interstellar war. General Ford teams up with General Eron Ryle (Grillo) and a team of elite soldiers in a race to stop the imminent attack before it is too late.Now heres the truth: This is the biggest sack of doggy doo to ever make it to the big screen with name stars like Bruce and Frank.
These guys are just phoning in their performances from another galaxy that doesn't even have 5G.
Their pay checks are only boosting their Superannuation funds and not helping the cause of cinema one bit.
I'm a big Willis and Grillo fan, but guys you should be ashamed.
Instead see Grillo in "Boss Level" that's a fun SciFi movie with a sharp sense of humour and remember Bruce from his Die Hard days.
"Cosmic Sin" director and writer, Edward Drake should also be ashamed.
Rotten Tomatoes are having a field day with his gem.
I believe this is his directorial debut on a major motion picture and mainly hired for his writing, which on this occasion is one of the lamest scripts I've ever heard uttered on the big screen.
Did they not do a table reading before shooting?
The movie was also co-written by Producer, Corey Large, who handles the sidekick role of Dash on screen.
Sidekicks are meant to be funny.
At one point this sexist pig of a character points to a female soldiers' huge phallus type gun and says, "Candle you handle that?"
To which she replies (cutting him off at the knees figuratively), "I've had bigger!"
It's supposed to be an Action, Sci Fi, Mystery And Thriller, but it's NOT!
The movie riffs off StarGate science and technology and the space armour is clearly spray painted plastic and awkward.
Bathroom time would be a challenge.
The film features a cosmic cannon which would have been better used to shoot this movie into outer space where it can become the Space Junk it was truly meant to be.
I wanted to walk out, but it was 90 minutes in air-conditioned comfort during a stinking hot March day in Queensland, Australia and besides I had a good supply of popcorn and drink and was curious to see if it could get better.
It didn't!
Launch your own preemptive strike and save your money for some really good films from this genre coming soon to a cinema near you like "Godzilla vs Kong".
I only gave this movie ONE star, because the rating system doesn't go to zero!
Worst movie for 2021....so far!

No badassery, no epic shootouts (neither deafening firepower like Aliens nor thoughtful suspense like Clint and Eli clearing out the ghost town on the Good Bad and Ugly). Nothing at all worthwhile to an adult intelligence in this film. I'm actually laughing at the thought that I watched it.

Let me say, I often love low budget sci-fi and fantasy movies. I have done since the 80s, but it's usually when you can see passion and effort put into something, even if it's rough around the edges.What makes me not only disappointed but a little sad about movies like Cosmic Sin, is that you can tell most of the people behind it simply didn't care. It's either so cheap that with a name like Bruce Willis it becomes profitable regardless of effort, or it's some kind of tax write-off.Of all the amateur writers and film-makers out there, I'm sure they could have found someone looking for an opportunity to make the best of a low-budget, and see it as an opportunity to make the best small movie they can. The resources are there... A few of the actors in Cosmic Sin are actually not bad, and known from other TV shows and small movie parts, and some of the visual effects actually aren't bad, so it's a shame to see the talents and skills of those people wasted on this dire effort. I suppose at least a couple of the effects people will have something half-decent for their showreel...The scriptwriter/s, director and editor/s should frankly be ashamed of themselves. A low budget does _not_ have to mean a bad film (not this bad, anyway), and when you have an opportunity and squander it like this, you should do the honourable thing and find a new career. Or at the very least step back, take a long hard look at your work and then take the time to do something you can have even a little pride in before churning out something like this.

Review title: Not the worst, but pretty bad
Review_body: This could be one of the most uninspired movies I've ever seen. The plot goes something like this. Willis' character is supposedly the notorious character who followed orders to release a 'q-bomb' on another planet and killed lots of beings. Suddenly on a planet which is supposed to be uninhanbited, a few members of the "alliance" are attacked by an unknown source, believed to be an alien and no one knows for sure. And then, when it becomes apparent that there are problems, grizzled Willis must be brought back one more time to potentially do the dirty deed to protect the world because they think they need to... because it's an alien group.Frank Grillo enters and brings his usual A-game and is fine. He does what he can with his part to at least look interested and try to be convincing. The bit characters are mostly OK with some rough edges. Willis looks tired, annoyed and like he couldn't be more disinterested throughout the film. Even during one of the most "intense" parts when he could be destroyed, the camera pans on him and he's got a look of boredom.The problem is that most of the film feels like total filler. Characters use terms you've heard in numerous other space movies to describe stuff that is supposed to be "space cool" to make you buy into the fact that wearing spacesuits (and only spacesuits) to travel millions of miles is a good idea. Doesn't quite work.To sum up how poor the dialogue in this film is, one of the characters has problems with the space flight path. So he says "AI, adjust flight path." Why would a human need to tell the AI to adjust a flight path? We don't even do that today, and certainly not hundreds of years in the future, which looks a LOT like it does today.So how does the story resolve? Like numerous others you've heard before, just far more talky, which is a very bad thing, and without much of it really making too much sense to be believeable. It's watchable for the laughs but totally pointless.

It seems like there's a great story buried somewhere here, there are some actors we know can be good, and the special effects are mostly quite decent. But it just doesn't work.Hard to say exactly what went wrong, but the three I think might be key reasons:* The camera shots are frequently messed up. Sometimes you know something's supposed to be happening, but between awkward angles, blur effects, and darkness, you don't know what they're trying to show you. Other times you know what they're trying to show you because half the scene gets it across, but another half doesn't match: like a shot with a main character staring out at the enemy, a cut to show enemies dying, back to the character now in close up even with some gun flashes, back to more enemies dying - but the character isn't actually holding up his gun.* There's no character development, yet key scenes are built around the assumption that there is. You're clearly supposed to feel empathy for the decisions they have to make, but you've never had a chance to build up any affinity with them in the first place. Not to mention they're all antagonistic towards each other, and yet in the end you're given the impression they've developed close bonds.* It can't decide what it wants to be. It's hyper futuristic in one case (their spacesuits border on high fantasy magic), while very mundane in others (a pretty standard pistol; no face protection on their suits, and some fist fights). It tries to be stylish (the Tarantino or Keanu kind) in some places, but attempts to be more grounded and dramatic (like Armageddon or The Day After Tomorrow) in others, completely failing at both. Sometimes it borderlines on arthouse, but isn't.Oh, and there are multiple hints at potential plot developments that go nowhere. Are they intentional red herrings? We'll never know, because the acting was so poor you don't know if some implications were accidental. Either way, any of those red herrings panning out would have made for a more interesting plot.Maybe one day there'll be a reboot that makes it all work.

Review title: Investors In This Project Were Clearly Duped
Review_body: Although this film isn't quite as bad as Ariels (2016), it's a very close second. Cosmic Sin is director and co-writer Edward Drake's second production and makes it appear most of the budget likely went to the actors, such as Bruce Willis and maybe Drake, himself. The highly recognizable and capable talent pool is obviously there, but a poorly crafted script, almost nonexistent production values and bad direction makes everyone and everything appear utterly amateurish. The cinematography is OK, but there's minimal green screen usage. It's as if they intentionally spent absolutely as little as possible on sets and props; literally a shoe string budget. A minimalist approach would have likely been more impressive than this. Investors in this project were clearly gaslit by producers. I'm utterly amazed this project was ever green lighted in the first place.

500 years in the future and they're still using fossil fuels and conventional weapons? REALLY? I mean.. Really?!Apart from the distinct lack of a "Phased plasma rifle with a 40-watt range", this film has some enjoyable moments, such as Bruce Willis being his usual cool collected self during a bar fight. But the film says nothing. No soul, no real drama. I wanted to be on the edge of my seat having looked at the premise... I sincerely have had more tension and drama on the edge of my toilet seat than when I was watching this movie.Once the aliens appear then it goes full pelt into an alien-zombie type battle that is somewhat reminiscent of James Cameron's "Aliens" from 1986. The cinematography also is worth noting in its a throwback to "Blade Runner" at times, but these are rare and the body of the film looks good and reasonable, but nothing creatively new.Rather long-winded and somewhat boring sequences ensue, some with potentially romantic undertones, along with recollections of past war wounds and pathetic sentimental dialogue that smacks of being added as an afterthought once a first edit was screened, the studio realising the movie has no emotion. Which it still doesn't.Some of it is fun, the special effects although I usually hate CGI are passable, but the lack of humanity and drama, unfortunately, makes the film fail on an emotional level, where it really could have been something that excels.As I have said it also fails miserably on a dramatic level... they just phoned it all in. What a waste of money this was."Die Hard" managed to pack in more drama and emotion, it's a shame that Bruce Willis and filmmakers of today don't seem to be capable or even willing to endeavour to achieve anything that even remotely compares. 2/10.

You would have been better to try a Fifth Element 2 than this Jason X meets Riddick.The directing was just awful, the lines were COMPLETELY unbelieveable from the start. Review title: You can tell they really tried...
Review_body: It really isn't as horrible as a lot of people are saying. It's obvious this was done on a limited budget but most the time it feels like they knew how to work on a limited budget. Most of the CGI is passable considering current state of tech. The costumes have a good amount of detail but it looks like a bunch of cosplayers were hired out to make them, painfully obvious EVA foam and thermoplastic. The "futuristic" armor pieces are almost comically ill-fitting and awkward but have enough detail to make it tolerable. Combat is rather non-sensical, they clearly did whatever felt cool and didn't cost any extra and paid minimal attention to any kind of real tactics or gunplay. The story progression makes sense if only by a thread. Nothing wrong with the acting. Cinematography absolutely feels like it's done on a budget but it's done well enough. Foley is well done if not a little too clean sometimes. Music is quite possibly the highpoint, absolutely spot on.

Review title: Skip right to the 25 min mark.
Review_body: As a big fan of cheesy B-rated sci-fi and horror films, I had hoped the combination of Bruce Willis and Frank Grillo might give some young director's script life.This is not a script that needed life.The first half hour could have easily been a low-rent zombie flick with not much going for it.Instead, by attempting to create a sci-fi world five hundred years in the future, yet showing an essentially modern earth, and completely failing to pay attention to even the most basic of details like the progression of vehicular or sidearm technology, the world feels weird and imbalanced.After the half-hour mark, we end up with a film that is entirely dependent on having Bruce Willis inside a suit of cheap cosplay exo-armor. Plot points are unclear, storyline progression is scattered.There are a handful of good shots and halfway clever lines, and the sniper character is charming enough, but it easily could have been a 45-min short film, and would have been much better for it.

Review title: Bruce has Become the NEW Nicholas Cage!
Review_body: If you haven't been paying attention, look at IMDB for Bruce Wilis and observe hire MANY horribad low budget movies he's made. No other "once A-list" actor since Nick Cage has taken this unexplainable route.I also suspect Bruce has a health issue because the number of his speaking lines in these movies is really limited...which would explain a lot, aside of his ego trying to stay relevant even if the plane is going down in flames with these movies.Maybe an accountant has mathematically shown that more money can be made taking this route than making a high quality streaming TV series, but Bruce has firmly chosen this road and is ruining his once admirable legacy.The movie is symbolic of the above....Take into for example the first 15 minutes. Human crew made contact and are infected and are taken into decontamination. No protocol is used as the space ship lands. The wisecracking soldiers walk the individuals inside as if the granma just arrived for Sunday supper...even though one girl is shoulder twerking with a white face and an ugly blister on her nose, another dude has also abnormal veins on his white face, etc. They get "decontaminated" in a shower area that looks like it belongs to a fitness gym by a dude in a painters outfit with a fire extinguisher. When all hell breaks loose and infected start attacking, the base alarm goes off...but no soldiers really come aside of the two that just died and were hesitant to shoot even as base people were dying. The Doctor doesn't want them dead at this point b/c they're beautiful to her. When the base goes on lockdown, the lights go red--the lights are the kind you buy at Home Depot and stick them against the shower tile of this "gym". The battle area now cuts into a bigger warehouse, like the stock room of your local Target.The actors have blooper smirks(!) on their face throughout these scenes even as they're dying. The scene gets resolved with Bruce Willis "John Wayne walking" into the scene with a missile launcher and taking out the brood with an "explosion" that is weaker than a 4th of July kids party. The explosion is so wea(!)but takes out the brood at the extreme ends. LOL! At one point in an earlier scene, the Dr. Smirkingly says "I'm a doctor not a God" when one soldier asks her to fix his friend who's been shot in the head (YES!... Quality screenwriting!)OH YES! I wanna see the Director's Cut and actor commentary!Ok no more piling on the hate. This "movie"(?) is what it is.My prayers go out to Bruce that he comes to his senses and figures out the sunset of his career.

Review title: Makes you wonder what could have been
Review_body:
A strong opening act shows cracks that eventually become chasms of mediocrity. The concept is quite good and really feels like the sort of thing you dreamed up in your nerd-driven fantasy of what could happen in a cool sci-fi storyline, but when the budget gets you Bruce "Anything for a Buck" Willis and a bunch of special effects worthy of mid-90s SyFy TV shows, you end up feeling like you've just been lied to. Frank Grillo gets top billing but is on screen for about 5 minutes.
Mid to late movie direction is particularly poor, as you sometimes enter the zone of "spooky ghostly characters in the dark" and dudes in plastic outfits that bear no resemblance or relation to the interesting type of antagonist encountered in the first act.The redeeming quality is that it makes you think about what a cool story this could have been if it had a giant budget. It could have been longer, more fleshed out, and not look like half the movie takes place in a garage.
Slow pace with no action or substance. Third grade Hollywood. Bruce Willis may have done it just for the money. Total crap. Without any proper plot and all acting is just dumb.

Review title: Cosmic Sin Vs Breach. Why the same movie?
Review_body:
This review will be as sporadic as the this movies script.I love Bruce Willis. However, either his agent or Hollywood is trying to end his career. He still gave a solid performance, but the script was not put together well at all. Certain lines and scenes lead to nowhere. I mean, really, the sunglass scene with the kid and Dash? What was that? At least the sunglasses weren't on General Ryle like they were on Admiral Adams in Breach.SPEAKING OF
Breach vs Cosmic SinWas this Edward Drake's and Corey Large's attempt at redeeming themselves from Breach OR just another attempt to ruin Bruce's image.Same movie, swap out actors center around Bruce, and make another bad film. At least the F/X were a little bit better (and that's not saying much).So Bruce still plays the same role. Clay young becomes James Ford. Former Hard Charging Military Combat Officer reduced to drinking but still a bad arse.They swapped out Thomas Jane for Frank Grillo (without shades but same disposition) and gave them the same fate. AND I mean THE SAME FATE! Instead of giving Grillo a daughter, we gave him a relative in Braxton (Brandon Lee) to be over protective of and with reverse love interest with the Fiona. Swapped out Timothy Murphy for Costas Mandylor (with accents) and slightly different outcomes but still the SAME FATE. And we are ready to ... Not do much but the same as before.PLOTS: Okay slightly different plot where we in Breach mess up the earth (which we are doing now) vs Aliens coming to claim us and the earth/galaxy. BUT still based on Aliens able to inhabit human bodies. I get why in Breach, but what was the point in Cosmic Sin? They already have bodies. Again BAD Alien visuals. Okay Horrible. The Cosmic Sin Aliens were in plastic Priest outfits. And please explain to me why a highly advanced alien race chooses to charge into battle with sometimes swords and other times guns? This contradicts earlier when Dr. Lea points out, "they learned how to use our weapons in seconds"? UHM, they looked just like the ones they were firing later on.Again please make up your mind about the weapons. Bullets or Lasers (same issue in Breach)?Noticeable mention/shout out. I carried a SAW in the military, and to see CJ PERRY (AKA LANA) one-handed carry around that cannon laser made question if i ever lifted a weight in my life. She was a beast.Scene transistion:
When Ford went to the armory to get a weapon at the beginning of the movie, how did he end up with NOT what he grabbed in the next scene when he uses it? He grabbed big laser rifle but instead showed up in the following scene shooting what looked like a Rocket Launcher when he took out the initial invading force on the base? Not even going to get into the scene where he is escorted into a cave with the cast of Cirque Du Soleil at the entrance. Tell me why the one alien is one arm and foot hanging on the tree? Where the hell did Braxton come from? Oh and what was that fight scene about between Braxton and the Alien?It's as though the directors did not care about the set, yet again. We are five centuries in the future using quantum physics to transport people hundreds of thousands of light-years away, yet we are still showing 600-year-old technology in the form of combustible engine pick-up trucks. Couldn't borrow some vehicles from Elon? Oh, let's not forget the motorcycle. But yet we have scenes of flying cars in the skyline one scene then a freeway with old vehicles the next. Speaking of transporting. Those "space suits" are able to allow you to survive in outer space without any form of Oxygen tanks (must be that 500 year new tech) And allow you to zoom through outer space, re enter another planets atmosphere not burn up and LAND the perfect landing that would make any gymnast blush but not correct when you bump into your fellow soldier? This was a mess.. Clearly they haven't read recent headlines FC has already happened according to the US Airforce.

I've got a pretty high tolerance for schlock(I've seen all 7 Tremors movies, AND the Show. I'm a huge Resident Evil Film Franchise fan. I could go on.) and honestly even I had a hard time getting through this one. I expected Bruce Willis to be sleepwalking his way through, like most films he's done in the last decade, but I didn't expect Frank Grillo to be pulling the same stunt.The younger less known set of actors try to put some flavor into it and the script seems to be trying for some sort of "is war just" point, but the nebulously defined zombie/fantasy/scifi aliens make any ''''''deep''''' quotes feel haphazard and pretentious.The sets are basic, all of the action taking place on either A) a greenscreen, B) cement bunker or C) A rough greenscreen trying to approximate space. In still images, the sort of armor suits the characters wear look cool, however any time an actor moves, it's clear they're just plastic shells hastily velcro'd onto the actor in some sort of wetsuit.All that would be entirely excusable if the actual plot, or characters, or world was engaging. It's not. It feels like a lesser Halo plot only with less nuance, less character, and unfortunately a very "Kill them all" attitude.Skip it.

I love a sci-fi/space movie, so I tend to be quite lenient with them. Having said that, this one: terrible.The acting was okay. Not great. Some terrible spots. Bruce wasn't good. At all. Most others were just okay. Shoot, even the story might have been okay. But the screenplay was just bad. Bad dialogue. Bad scenes. I had a bad feeling when the movie opened up with like 5 F-bombs (just to be clear, I personally have absolutely no issue with bad language). Nothing screams "I'm trying to be an edgy film, you better take me seriously!" like opening up with 5 F-bombs. Ugh. And Bruce. I don't know if he needed some beer money, or this was a personal favor to a friend or something, but I would have figured a quick pass through the script and he would have been like "Nope." But not the case. I attribute his wooden, "I don't care" acting to the fact that he must have agreed without reading the script, saw what he got himself into, figured it was too late to back out, so phoned in his lines.And then right at the beginning when the alien-human things land in the ship (I'm not listing this as a spoiler since it's literally like 20 min into the movie) at the base, and there is literally no containment or ANYTHING between the 5 people that showed up for First Contact (seriously - this is supposed to be a BIG DEAL, First Contact, and there are like 5 people there for it?) so of course when the alien-humans start killing people there is no containment, no quarantine. Just everyone right there, all ready to be infected or something. It's just simply stupid. It's lazy writing, it's clear that the plot requires it for Edgy F-bomb Action and Awesome Gun Shootings. It's terrible. Completely unbelievable.So I gave up. It's not worth the time to finish. But hey, it's nice to know people are driving what appear to be gas powered Jeeps 500 years in the future. Seriously, it's set 500 years in the future (FIVE. HUNDRED. YEARS.!) and the cars they drive on roads look exactly like what you see today. I weep for the future.Give this one a miss. Trust me. Unless you are studying bad films or something.

Review title: How did this movie ever come to be?
Review_body: The question that came to mind after the first 5 minutes of this. I admit. Bruce Willis was the only reason I considered watching this. But with a number of actors I did not recognize, and had all the markers of being a low budget looking film. Hmm... Bruce must have been bored and needed something to do and was paid a big chunk of change to do this or was doing a favor for someone trying to get their foot in the door of the film industry.As others stated, the advancement of humans and technology nowhere matched what one would expect for the time period set for this movie. This looks like it is set in say... the year 1994 with the exception of the space crafts.I've seen more futuristic characters, imaginative set designs, makeup, wardrobe and creativity in 22+ year old films like "the 5th Element","the Matrix", "Alien"; a 42 year old movie which STILL holds its own and let us not forget "2001: A Space Odyssey" released in 1968 - a now 53 year old film.All this film delivered were a multitude of recognizable rip-offs from dozens of 90's sci-fi films and TV shows with a script sounding like it was written by a teenager and a forgettable story.Poor direction combined with horrible dialogue and poor acting make for a tedious film watching experience.Any moments that should be suspenseful fall flat and there's no chemistry between any of the actors. It almost feels as if they are all doing a dry run of the script while being filmed and in costume. Deaths and "shoot-em-up" scenes somehow lack any emotion, tension, or gravity; for me they evoked the same emotions as if I were watching a group of people standing in line waiting to check out at the grocery store. I was actually just distracted from the film just now by a number of birds that just flew past our office window and into a bush in the neighbor's yard - "What's going on!" I exclaimed. "8 sparrows just flew into a bush across the street into the same spot!" - "I wonder what's in there and what's going on?". Sorry, now back to my review - which I'm doing while sort of watching the film, but not really, anymore... as I've lost complete interest in it.Is there truly no imagination left in the film industry? This isn't the only piece of waste out there that somehow made it from script to screen instead of going to the scrap heap where it belongs. I'm sorry for being so harsh, but I just don't know how this movie ever came to be.This is definitely one of those films where one would say "That's 43 minutes of my life that I can't get back." *I started doing other things due to how bad this film was, so all told, I saw about 43 minutes of the film.Sorry guys, I'm going to give this a HUGE thumbs down.Save yourself the time and invest your time doing anything other than watching this. You've been warned!

Review title: University Film Students Make a C-Grade Space Movie!
Review_body: It seems that Bruce Willis and Frank Grillo were somehow conned into appearing in this low-budget, C-grade movie, that was obviously made by less-than-talented University "Film" students. The script is often cringeworthy, nonsensical and cliche, and the lighting, makeup, costumes and supporting cast are really not much better. The sound and occasional CGI scenes are OK, so I'll award one star for that, plus one star for Frank Grillo and the final star goes to Bruce Willis. Unfortunately, nothing else in this movie deserves a star. I actually feel very generous giving this movie this 3 stars. TLDR: It's not great.

Review title: Cosmic Sin - Yes it is a sin.
Review_body: This movie is horrible, in all imaginable ways. The duo Edward Drake and Corey Large seems to have some deal with Bruce Willis and i guess its plain and simple. "Bruce, i get to direct the movie, Corey gets a part in it and you get 90% of the budget as pension money. Sounds good?"The movie is supposed to take place 500 years into the future. But nothing feels futuristic. Actually the feeling is rather that civilization taken steps back, and some generals and ex generals takes some decisions of erradicating a alien civilization without running it past the government. The future technology has no thought behind it, and seems just play a part in giving the author to this movie loop holes to build their story around.Why Bruce Willis takes part in this crap is beyond me. Once he was a somewhat regarded actor, but perhaps the deal i described above is too good to turn down.Nothing makes sense, not the scenery, not the acting, not the plot or the fact that aliens apparently prefeer to use spears and swords when attacking hoomans with automatic weaponry. Drake, Large and Willis has more projects going on, and my only lingering question is who the fxxx finance this crap? Does Drake or Large have rich family? I cant think Bruce finance any of it. And im not suggesting it has a big budget, but still some money have to gone into it and that is baffling.Dont waste your time on this one. The only reason to watch it is to see how utterly worthless it is as a movie.The only sin here is that the movie was made to begin with.

Review title: We wanted Halo we got Cosmic Shame
Review_body:
Let me first start by saying I had looked forward to this film. The potential of a franchise launching opportunity was there. The right cast was hired, and the story had potential.I can only assume that director Edward Drake never believed in it, or was looking simply for a quick paycheck. I can say Drakes career can only go up from here.The acting is sloppy, the dialog is 1999. The CGI had to been purchased off Fiverr to reduce costs. What could have been super cool the battle armor, was cosplay if you had a good budget but not skill. The scene where they try and put on their helmets was absolutely painful. They had to cut scene it because the actors could not get it on.As I said by the title we wanted Halo, we had hoped for a character to charm us like Master Chief. Nope. Instead we got a old grizzled character that we are introduced getting drunk and ends getting drunk. So everything in between is a hangover...which would explain the dialog or lack of.I would have like to cheer for some of the characters, but honestly they all could have died and we would have not noticed. The really only important person is the Engineer that everyone constantly puts down. Nice stereotyping in 2500.This is such a bad flick most reviewers never got past the first 20 minutes. I stayed for the whole thing, but wanted to fast forward after 15. This flick will be forgotten by end of the week, but it could have been amazing. I wonder if what was dropped on the cutting room floor could have made it better.One star for making it to the box office
the second star for having the occasional pithy line or reference.

The only sin here is the lack of any cohesive thought in writing producing and directing this awful movie. Sad to see good actors and actresses get handed a script of crap. There is.evidence that the writers may have read Starship Troopers by Robert A. Heinlein (GOAT of SciFi authors) and used his Nova bomb as describe in Starship Troopers 3: Marauder and Starship Troopers: Traitor of Mars; "There has been controversy on Earth over the use of the Q Bomb: Religious fanatics say that the Federation shouldn't decide what planet lives and dies; politicians don't bother; and military officials think that since the Bugs don't use a Q Bomb, why shouldn't they?" This sad movie attempts to be part HALO, part StarShip Troopers, part Astronaut's Wife, part I don't know what the Fubar. It rambles and stumbles it's way across the screen like an alien bug shot so full of plot holes that it's raining blood and bad lines till it finally collapses in a fit of flatulence, writhing on the theater floor, spilled popcorn and milk duds scattering in all directions, like sparks from a broken dynamo. The green screen, is cheep, the FX only add to the unrealism, there is no sense of immersiveness, and Bruce delivers his worst performance since Hudson Hawk. Spare your eyes and ears and move on from this cosmic cosplayed out weirdness.

Review title: Mystery of this film is Why Was It Made?
Review_body:
500 years of progress and this is what we have to show for it?It really feels like nobody wanted to make this movie but someone made them do it. Nobody had anything to say. Anything to add. Nothing we haven't seen a million times before. Screenplay has nothing whatsoever to say or convey and is full of clichés, just like it would be if you never wanted to write it in the first place, but had to. For a grade, or something.Clearly, there was no excess money to burn - almost entire scenography is some kind of paintball course. And some forest. And all the crops are close-ups of people doing stuff, mostly shooting off into something offscreen, presumably into the distance.The movie is set in the 26th century, with the space and time bending human species spanning three planets (only indication of this is an introductory text) and the weirdest thing we can see in the galaxy is a girl with semi-yellow hair? Everything else, technology, weapons, fashion, everything looks exactly as today. Alright, excepting a few seconds long filler scenes of spaceships.I'm writing this because one question baffles me without cease. It's - Why did you have to make this? What was the motivation behind this work? I don't see you making any money, however inadequate the investment was. What's the point?
I'd really like to know.If this is some kind of student project movie, then its kinda cool. If you go to school with the guys who made this then you should really have a go at it. Otherwise...

To proclaim this as a (DvD), movie masterpiece, would streach anyone's mental capability.Amidst last 4 of 12, (since 2018 for Willis), this Sci-Fantasy film, shows every hallmark of being drastically under prepared once the principle actors were informed of the Pandemic restrictions pending & whole production went into 3 takes only mode.Around which some of the world's fastest editing must have been given only most rudimentary quality control.Real challenge for viewers is to comprehend the plot, and where the movie develops some creative purpose.It's production features elements akin to being a poorly realised 'Steam-Punk', story ineptly re-styled towards a convention centre cos-play re-enactment.Considering the strong evocation of themes within 'Edge of Tomorrow' and corresponding good visuals of Bruce and Frank, in enhanced armour; yet devoid of any true nihilist wit, the weakness surely resides with having a bland script.Putting aside, the main cast, manages to elevate slightly roles that would otherwise go completely ignored. Short co-star parts are common in established sci-fi / action films (especially female), and we are granted here two contrasting women co-stars that have to be given attention otherwise you miss key movie themes.Action scenes vary from generic to plain idiotic, so we can only hope stunt people attached get granted a hefty sympathy vote towards their next projects.Lastly, the soundtrack. Yes, it actually has one. Again, with contracted time involved, sound engineering must've been stressed to amass most basic of effects, such that during the few tracks played through scenes barely any emotional synchronicity can be found.With minimal scenes, the movies bankable featured actor, actually doesn't do himself any harm, nor favours. Placing Bruce's performance firmly aligned with 'Last Man Standing', just below 'Armageddon'.Overall - A par-boiled and half plucked turkey, that stands a slender chance of being that elusive future un-discovered stars mythical rare gem.

I haven't written a movie review on here in years, but really needed to for this one. I saw the trailer, read the reviews and thought "nah, no way Bruce Willis would go down in a fiery crash with his acting career doing below F grade movies." Well, I was wrong. So VERY wrong. The reviews here are point on. I wish I could give this a movie a zero. It was the worst crap I've seen all year.I don't know if Bruce owes someone money or everyone in this film is hurting for cash because of COVID. It sucked BADLY. Seriously save your time and skip this one. It had everything bad that you could think of in a movie.The plot was weak and missing any details that would've made this movie somewhat interesting. The actors looked like they didn't care to be there, especially Bruce who seemed drunk or stoned most of the time. Also, the actions of the characters made absolutely no sense "put your hands up" to people that are decaying and zombie-looking. What the hell?!The editing was nauseating at best. The dialogs, oh god the dialogs were long and boring. Yak yak yak with pointless fillers that only extended the torture of trying to watch this.The CGI was mediocre at best. My pre-teen daughter plays with Blender and can do a WAY better job that what they did in this movie for CGI effects. The props were also pretty bad. Someone on here stated their suit of armour looked like plastic. No, it wasn't plastic, more like spray-painted foam with two colored LEDs mounted on each side of their heads. I have a 3D printer and I can make way better props than the ones used in this film. The music kept repeating the same annoying rhythms and drowning out the dialogs at times (may be I should be thankful for that).I found myself fast forwarding a lot through this movie HOPING for something good, for ANYTHING to redeem this crap that was wasting my precious time, but I was sorely disappointed. I can go on and on about how bad this was but I feel I've ranted enough. Please trust the reviews here, they are right. If not just trust me and avoid this one like the plague.

Review title: From someone who worked with many props
Review_body: Just a side note, what makes this movie confusing is Willis and Grillo. This would be a fine sci fi attempt as a budget movie, but having two mega stars brings to light they had money and seemed to use it all on these two.Props: So having being in the prop world for a very long time. In movies using polyvinyl (pvc) is almost a dead method, except for budget movies. Everything from their armour to weapons look like plastic, and no matter the skill of the artist you can't really be convinced it's metal. Willis armour is probably painted the bettern painted due to the use of colour. But everyone else's literally looks like plastic and even with the "clang" sound effects you can tell they're moving in plastic. Where I was done is the small woman carrying a 2 metre futuristic 50 cal sniper with one hand. It bounces around like it's made of foam. It doesn't help keep you convinced this world is real. Also at one point the enemy is carrying a sword and it literally looks like a foam sword used for casting. It's not even slightly convincing or menacing.CGI: Given the horrible props the CGI was actually quite good! I would have rather see CGI armour, while not a preferred practice I think it would have helped.Story: literally couldn't keep up or understand wtf was happening Haha. It was a choppy ridiculous mess.

I enjoy Sci-Fi films, sometimes even "low-budget" flicks because they can provide a "once-in-a-while" dive into something that hasn't been thought up. Some independent studios create excellent digital shorts pertaining to Sci-Fi, so I try to give many of these movies a chance. The best part, from my perspective, is that Sci-Fi can provide a deep and interesting framework from which they derive an engaging story, even with a low budget.This film failed to provide the deep and engaging material that one hopes for in a Sci-Fi movie. The scenes were rushed, thrown together, leaving the viewer asking way too many questions about how things ended up the way they were or blatantly laughing at the lack of thought put into the plot. It was empty-feeling, failing to draw me into the film. Perhaps others will experience something different, but this was not a well-made movie. Corny dialogue plagued the film, along with major jumps in the plot or setting with characters just showing up without much explanation.Dialogue - 2/10
Special FX - 7/10
Plot Depth - 1/10Overall - 2/10I did not enjoy watching this film.

This movie isn't for everyone, clearly. A bit of a shame really, as it's a classic sci-fi adventure that revolves around exploring an interesting premise.This movie, if turned into a short-fiction novel, would make for a fun Sunday read, even if a bit geeky in nature.Where this movie loses some critics is that it is a low-budget film, with a big-name actor being the only surface-level attraction. If you accept it as a made-for-TV movie rather than a blockbuster, you may be more easily look past its limitations.The premise of the movie is how should terrains, spacefaring humans, react to first contact with a suspected aggressive alien race. Some movies with such a premise play out the notion of humans being being dominated by the aliens and enslaved, which is what critics love to see. This movie takes an aggressive opposing stance, even more so than Ender's Game, and argues for swift action over weakness."I was late once and so he broke my nose. I was never late again."Geeky Easter eggs exist in the movie, such as the space battleships you see appear to be StarCraft Terran Battlecruisers. It helps to explain the universe without needing to say much at all; something critics would miss.Like most of Bruce Willis movies these days, they run counter to modern liberal norms. I'm giving this movie a 7/10, as there were some cheesy fight scenes and some of the props looked a bit silly. The story was a bit abrupt at times, which might cause issues for viewers that need things spelled out for them, but I didn't have that issue myself.Overall, I enjoyed watching it.
